description: From Middle English disjoynen, from Old French desjoindre, from Latin disiungere (“to separate”), from dis-, di- (“apart”) + iungere (“to join”).

verbs.description: disjoin (third-person singular simple present disjoins, present participle disjoining, simple past and past participle disjoined)

examples: Never let us lay down our arms against France, till we have utterly disjoined her from the Spanish monarchy.
